questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a diffuse, itchy rash and swollen face for 6 hours. That morning, she was diagnosed with an abscess of the lower leg. She underwent treatment with incision and drainage and was prescribed oral antibiotics. She has no history of serious illness. She is not in acute distress. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows mild swelling of the eyelids and lips but the tongue and oropharynx are unaffected. There are multiple erythematous patches and wheals over her upper extremities, back, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. After discontinuing all recently administered drugs and beginning continuous vital sign monitoring, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intramuscular epinephrine and intravenous hydrocortisone administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expectant management (i.e., watchful waiting) is appropriate for patients with mild type 1 hypersensitivity reactions (i.e., symptoms limited to the skin or mild symptoms affecting only one organ system). Because this patient has widespread pruritic lesions and angioedema, symptomatic treatment should be initiated.

B) INCORRECT:

H2 antihistamines (e.g., famotidine) can be used in the treatment of allergic reactions, such as urticaria and anaphylaxis. However, they are only used in severe cases and should be administered in combination with an H1 antihistamine and not as monotherapy. A different first-line treatment is more appropriate for this patient.

C) CORRECT:

In suspected type I hypersensitivity reactions due to acute drug allergy, it is first necessary to discontinue all recently administered drugs and rule out anaphylaxis using the diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis. Second-generation H1 antihistamines (e.g., cetirizine) should then be administered to reduce symptoms. Patients with widespread urticaria and/or angioedema should also receive oral glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone), which combat delayed recurrence but require several hours to take effect. Continuous monitoring for signs of anaphylaxis (e.g., hypotension) and/or airway obstruction in patients with type 1 hypersensitivity reactions is required.

Suspected type I hypersensitivity reactions can be confirmed with in vivo skin testing, allergen-specific IgE tests, and/or serum tryptase test. Because this patient still requires antibiotic therapy for her abscess, the causative drug should be substituted with an unrelated medication.

D) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular epinephrine is the most important acute pharmacotherapy for anaphylaxis and is usually combined with corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone) after the patient is stabilized. Although this patient has a type I hypersensitivity reaction, she does not meet the diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis (e.g., hypotension, signs of respiratory compromise, gastrointestinal symptoms). Because she is still at risk of developing anaphylaxis, she should be continuously monitored until her symptoms resolve.

E) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation is indicated in patients with anaphylaxis and/or severe angioedema with signs of airway compromise (e.g., stridor, severe oral edema, respiratory difficulty). This patient only has mild angioedema with no respiratory difficulty and therefore does not require intubation at this time. Continuous monitoring for signs of anaphylaxis or airway compromise should be carried out to determine if intubation is required.
questions.hint: The patient presents with urticaria and angioedema that began shortly after starting a new medication, which suggests a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction caused by drug exposure.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, a 40-year-old man has retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated before arrival to the unit. He received 0.5 L of lactated Ringer solution intraoperatively. The patient was given morphine and ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago when the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and hypertension. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Wheezing is heard in both lungs. Breath sounds are decreased. The patient's face appears flushed. Watery nasal secretions and conjunctival injection are present. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of non-selective beta-blockers can result in bronchospasm due to the inhibition of β2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta-blocker that selectively inhibits β1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.

All beta-blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta-blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperinflation of the lungs in a patient with emphysema can result in iatrogenic alveolar rupture; a 20-pack-year smoking history and the recent mechanical ventilation (intubated patient!) are therefore risk factors for alveolar rupture. Alveolar rupture would result in a pneumothorax, which presents with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds on the side of the pneumothorax. This patient developed wheezing and decreased breath sounds bilaterally after an infusion of ketorolac, making alveolar rupture unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause flushing and bronchial inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another cause more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin by inhibiting the enzyme bradykinin dehydrogenase. Increased levels of bradykinin typically result in a dry cough or angioedema, neither of which is seen in this patient. Bradykinin does have some bronchoconstrictor effect, especially if the patient has an underlying airway hyperreactivity (bronchial asthma). However, Samter triad and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different mechanism for bronchospasm.
questions.hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma together constitute Samter triad.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a pruritic rash on his penis that has been present for the past hour. The rash developed shortly after the patient had protected sexual intercourse with his girlfriend for the first time. His girlfriend does not have any symptoms. Five days ago, the patient visited a friend who was complaining of intense pruritus on her elbows, wrists, groin, and axillae. The friend subsequently underwent treatment that required her to wash her bedding, clothing, and towels in hot water. Two years ago, the patient developed an itchy rash around his mouth after blowing up balloons at a birthday party. He is breathing comfortably. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques with mild excoriations that extend from the base to the glans of the penis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat certain viral infections, e.g., herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. While HSV infection should be considered as a differential diagnosis in a sexually active patient presenting with a genital rash, the timing and appearance of his rash are not consistent with this diagnosis (HSV typically appears 2–7 days after exposure and is characterized by vesicles and ulcerations). Furthermore, oral acyclovir is preferred over IV administration for genital HSV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical permethrin is used for the treatment of lice and scabies. This patient's friend has symptoms consistent with scabies, and while scabies is spread through close contact, the typical rash is characterized by elongated papules, red burrows, and scattered vesicles. This patient's rash is consistent with urticaria, against which permethrin is not effective.
Image Description:

Localization: periumbilical region

Lesion: papules, erythema, excoriations

Description: elongated, erythematous papules, inflamed nodules, and excoriations

C) INCORRECT:

Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer most commonly administered as an inhaled solution for the treatment of asthma. It can also be given as an oral solution for patients with mastocytosis. While this patient's urticaria is mediated by mast cell release of histamine, cromolyn sodium is not recommended for the treatment of hypersensitivity reactions.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous epinephrine is used for the treatment of anaphylaxis, a severe form of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. While urticaria is a common feature in anaphylaxis, this patient has no other symptoms to suggest it (e.g., bronchospasm, laryngeal edema, abdominal pain, hypotension). A different therapy is more appropriate for a mild to moderate localized reaction.

E) INCORRECT:

Famotidine is an H2 receptor blocker commonly used for the treatment of GERD and can also be used in the treatment of anaphylaxis. While acute-onset urticaria after exposure to a potential allergen should raise concern for anaphylaxis, this patient has no other symptoms to suggest anaphylaxis (e.g., bronchospasm, laryngeal edema, abdominal pain, hypotension) or GERD. A different therapy is more appropriate.

F) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a potent anti-inflammatory that has many uses, including the treatment of certain hypersensitivity reactions. Because glucocorticoids can cause serious systemic side effects, they are typically reserved for moderate to severe type 1 hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., angioedema, pronounced urticaria). If glucocorticoids are used for the treatment of urticaria, oral rather than intravenous administration is preferred. This patient has a mild to moderate localized hypersensitivity reaction, making another treatment more appropriate.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

G) CORRECT:

This patient's localized urticaria is consistent with a mild to moderate type 1 hypersensitivity reaction to latex, for which an H1-antihistamine such as cetirizine is indicated. Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are caused by preformed IgE antibodies (from prior sensitization), which then activate rapid histamine release from mast cells upon reexposure to the antigen. Cetirizine competes with histamine at the H1 receptor to stabilize mast cells and is less sedating than first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine, hydroxyzine). This patient should also be advised to avoid contact with latex in the future.
Image Description:

Anterior upper body of a man presenting with a pruritic rash after consuming peanuts

Multiple well-defined, raised, erythematous plaques of varying sizes are visible on the upper left abdomen and inner arm. The largest lesion on the trunk shows central clearing.

This is the typical appearance of urticaria (hives).
questions.hint: The eruption of an urticarial rash on the patient's penis shortly after protected sexual intercourse and history of a rash following exposure to balloons suggest a hypersensitivity reaction to latex.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial swelling and itching all over his body 1 hour after eating some trail mix. He does not have shortness of breath or hoarseness. He has never had a similar episode before. He has asthma treated with an albuterol inhaler, which he uses less than once a month. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Physical examination shows perioral swelling and urticaria over the face, neck, chest, and fingers of his right hand. There is no swelling of the oropharynx and no audible stridor. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Treatment with intravenous diphenhydramine is begun. Shortly after, pruritus and swelling improved, and the rash started to fade. Prior to discharge, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Advise to carry oral cetirizine at all times

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum mast-cell tryptase levels may indicate a type I hypersensitivity reaction. However, this study has a low sensitivity for food-triggered reactions and a normal result does not rule out anaphylaxis. It is not routinely indicated in the diagnosis of anaphylaxis or other type 1 hypersensitivity reactions.

B) INCORRECT:

The patch test is the gold standard for diagnosing contact dermatitis, a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. During a patch test, small amounts of potential contact allergens are applied to a patient's back for 48–72 hours to induce a local type IV hypersensitivity reaction and identify the irritant. This patient's presentation is more consistent with a type I hypersensitivity reaction, which requires an IgE skin prick test. In this test, small amounts of different allergens are applied to the skin with a lancet to penetrate the tissue and then observed for wheal development.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with known food allergies are at increased risk of anaphylaxis. This patient's reaction was relatively moderate, but the severity of previous allergic reactions does not predict the severity of future reactions, which could result in a more systemic reaction or life-threatening anaphylaxis. Accidental exposure is common and patients and their families should be prepared for potentially severe reactions. Patients should be prescribed epinephrine autoinjectors and provided with an anaphylaxis emergency action plan. This patient should also be referred to an allergist in order to identify and thus avoid the culprit allergen.

Allergy, asthma, and atopy are all type I hypersensitivities (the atopic triad), and a history of one type I hypersensitivity reaction is a risk factor for the development of another.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the patient responded well to an antihistamine, cetirizine's onset of action is around 20 minutes, which would be too long in the case of a more severe reaction in the future.

E) INCORRECT:

Steroids such as oral prednisone may be used as an adjunctive treatment for patients with moderate type I hypersensitivity reactions. However, this patient has responded well to intravenous diphenhydramine therapy and is currently asymptomatic. Corticosteroid therapy is not needed at this point.
questions.hint: This patient has urticaria and swelling after ingestion of a trail mix, which is consistent with a food-induced type I hypersensitivity reaction, likely attributable to an ingredient in the trail mix.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman returns to the physician's office because of an itchy rash that developed 2 hours after receiving an injection. This morning, she was diagnosed with uncomplicated pyelonephritis and the physician administered an intravenous injection of ceftriaxone and prescribed oral ciprofloxacin. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's skin findings?

choices.text: Tissue damage caused by the photochemical derivative of an antibiotic
Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells
Hyperpermeability of the superficial dermal microvasculature
IgE-independent mast cell activation in subcutaneous tissue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Perivascular cutaneous polymorphonuclear infiltration is typical of cutaneous small vessel vasculitides. Although these conditions can cause urticarial lesions after drug exposure, they more commonly manifest with painful, palpable purpura, and/or ulceration. Additionally, the symptoms of these conditions are immune complex-mediated (type III hypersensitivity reaction) and usually occur weeks after drug exposure, unlike this patient's acute-onset lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

A phototoxic drug reaction is the result of tissue damage caused by the photochemical derivative of a drug. A phototoxic drug reaction can occur with antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), tetracyclines, and sulfonamides, and manifest within hours of drug administration and exposure to the sun. However, this condition typically manifests as a diffuse sunburn of exposed skin, not the pruritic wheals seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions. Examples of drug-induced type IV hypersensitivity reactions involving the skin include exanthematous drug eruptions, erythema multiforme, drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. These conditions, however, manifest several hours to days after drug exposure and the characteristic rashes of these conditions have a different appearance. This patient presents with localized, urticarial lesions that developed more acutely.

D) CORRECT:

Beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillins and cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone) can cause acute urticaria by triggering IgE-mediated mast cell activation (type 1 hypersensitivity reaction). Mast cells release histamine and other vasodilatory and inflammatory mediators, which increase blood vessel permeability. Increased microvascular permeability in the superficial dermis is responsible for the formation of wheals. Increased permeability of blood vessels in the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue is responsible for angioedema.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's skin findings are caused by mast cell activation but are most likely the result of an IgE-mediated process that occurs in the superficial dermis. IgE-independent (direct) mast cell activation is caused by drugs such as opioids and vancomycin. Mast cell activation in the subcutaneous tissue or deep dermis would cause angioedema, which manifests as diffuse swelling rather than well-circumscribed papules.
questions.hint: The photograph shows well-circumscribed papules on an erythematous base (wheals), which are characteristic of urticaria.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, and swelling and pruritus of the lips, tongue, and throat for 1 hour. The symptoms began minutes after he started eating a lobster dinner. It is determined that his symptoms are due to surface crosslinking of IgE. This immunologic event most likely caused the release of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the immediate phase of anaphylactic reactions, surface crosslinking of IgE causes mast cell degranulation, which releases tryptase, histamine, heparin, and eosinophil chemotactic factors. Of these compounds, tryptase is a relatively specific marker of mast cell activation.

In the late phase of anaphylactic reactions, inflammatory cells (e.g., eosinophils) and cytokines mediate inflammation and tissue damage.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a blood smear

Mast cells are visible as multiple large purple cells containing copious amounts of cytoplasmic granules.

B) INCORRECT:

Cathepsin is a lysosomal enzyme released by neutrophils during type III hypersensitivity reactions, as seen in vasculitides and serum sickness. Although serum sickness (or a serum-sickness like reaction) may present with urticaria, this patient lacks other characteristic findings such as fever, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy. Moreover, serum sickness typically occurs 1–2 weeks after antigen exposure (unlike this patient's acute-onset symptoms). Cathepsin is not released by surface crosslinking of IgE.

C) INCORRECT:

Serotonin is released in high levels in carcinoid syndrome, which may present with abdominal pain and shortness of breath. However, carcinoid syndrome usually presents with additional symptoms, such as recurrent diarrhea and flushing. It does not cause facial swelling, and it is not mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE.

D) INCORRECT:

Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator responsible for facial swelling in patients with hereditary angioedema. In addition to facial swelling, some patients with hereditary angioedema also have gastrointestinal attacks that manifest with abdominal pain, similar to this patient. However, this condition does not cause urticaria or pruritus, and it is not mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE.

Acquired causes of C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency and ACE inhibitor therapy (which decreases levels of ACE responsible for the breakdown of bradykinin) can also cause bradykinin-mediated angioedema.

E) INCORRECT:

Interferon-gamma is secreted by natural killer cells and T cells and stimulates macrophages. This response occurs during type II hypersensitivity reactions and type IV hypersensitivity reactions. However, neither of these reactions play a role in anaphylaxis. Interferon-gamma is not released by surface crosslinking of IgE.
questions.hint: The patient's acute-onset abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, swelling, and pruritus after eating shellfish (a common allergen) are characteristic of an anaphylactic reaction. Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE on mast cells.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a painful lesion on his right leg. Yesterday, he received all of his scheduled childhood immunizations, including the second dose of the diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis vaccine, which was administered in the right quadriceps. Physical examination shows a 2-cm ulcer with surrounding induration over the right anterolateral thigh. A skin biopsy of the lesion shows localized edema, skin necrosis, neutrophilic infiltration, and complement deposition. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermal mast cell activation is the mechanism of a type I hypersensitivity reaction, such as atopic dermatitis, which occurs immediately after antigen exposure. Cutaneous manifestations include diffuse erythema, edema, and urticaria with pruritus, which is not consistent with this patient's lesion. Moreover, necrosis does not typically occur.
Image Description:

Erythematous, confluent plaques typical of urticaria that cover most of the skin on the antecubital fossa and the ventral side of the forearm.

B) CORRECT:

Immune complex deposition describes the mechanism of Arthus reaction, a localized type III hypersensitivity reaction that can occur 12 – 36 hours after intradermal injection of an antigen in pre-sensitized individuals (circulating antigen-specific IgG). This child was most likely sensitized to an antigen in the DTaP vaccine when he received it for the first time at 2 months of age (routine immunization schedule). DTaP is administered intramuscularly but inadvertent intradermal injection often occurs. The circulating antibodies combine with the antigen to form immune complexes, which trigger localized vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis by activating the classical complement pathway. An Arthus reaction is usually self-limiting.

C) INCORRECT:

Intradermal acantholysis is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, which can occur following administration of live attenuated vaccines as a result of a type II hypersensitivity reaction. However, pemphigus vulgaris typically results in the formation of multiple blisters and erosions unlike this patient with a single indurated ulcer.

D) INCORRECT:

Infective dermal inflammation is characteristic of cellulitis, which occurs secondary to intradermal inoculation of bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus) via minor skin injuries. Infection of the vaccination site is an extremely rare complication given the single-use vials and injection supplies that are used today. Furthermore, patients would present with a rapidly expanding erythematous skin lesion and systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, chills).

E) INCORRECT:

Examples of cutaneous T lymphocyte-mediated hypersensitivity (type IV hypersensitivity) reactions include allergic contact dermatitis, fixed drug eruptions, acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP), erythema multiforme (EM), and Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). AGEP, EM, and SJS can occur following administration of vaccines that contain additives such as aluminium or antimicrobials but these reactions typically begin more than 48 hours after vaccination and have a different appearance.
questions.hint: This patient's cutaneous reaction after receiving his second diphtheria and tetanus vaccine is consistent with an Arthus reaction.

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing an allogeneic skin graft procedure for extensive full-thickness burns involving his left leg, a 41-year-old man develops redness and swelling over the graft site. He has not had any fevers or chills. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F). Physical examination of the left lower leg shows well-demarcated erythema and edema around the skin graft site. The graft site is minimally tender and there is no exudate. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s skin condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Complement activation through the alternative pathway occurs in direct response to microbial cell surface molecules (e.g., bacterial endotoxins) rather than the formation of the antigen-antibody complex seen in the classic pathway. However, the absence of purulent discharge, tenderness, and fever makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated mast cell activation is the mechanism underlying type I hypersensitivity reactions (including anaphylaxis). Patients typically present immediately after exposure to an antigen with dyspnea, bronchospasm, hypotension, flushing, urticaria, pruritus, and/or abdominal pain. Examples of type I HSR include anaphylaxis, most drug allergies, and food allergies. This patient' s transplant rejection is caused by a different mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune complex-mediated complement activation is the mechanism of a type III hypersensitivity reaction, which is characterized by the deposition of IgG-antigen complexes in various tissues. Examples of type III HSR include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis. This patient's recent history of an allogeneic graft placement raises concern for a different mechanism of inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of surgical site infection > 4 days postoperatively. However, the absence of purulent discharge, tenderness, and fever makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Preformed antibody-mediated complement activation is the underlying mechanism of hyperacute transplant rejection, during which IgM and IgG antibodies bind to self-antigens that are mistakenly identified as foreign. This process triggers complement activation and inflammation. Hyperacute transplant rejection is an example of a type II HSR and typically presents with swelling, erythema, and sloughing at the site of the graft in the immediate postoperative period. This patient presents two weeks after graft placement making a hyperacute rejection unlikely.

F) CORRECT:

Th1 cell-induced macrophage activation is responsible for this patient's acute graft rejection. This type IV hypersensitivity reaction is triggered by foreign antigens from the allogeneic skin graft, which incite host T-cell sensitization. Continued exposure to the foreign antigen causes the pre-sensitized T cells to activate macrophages and thus induce an inflammatory reaction in the tissue. In addition, this exposure leads to antibody-mediated complement activation (similar to hyperacute transplant rejection), during which IgM and IgG antibodies develop in response to foreign antigens from an allogeneic graft. This reaction most commonly presents as redness, swelling, itching, and tissue sloughing at the graft site.

Treatment involves removal of the graft and replacement with an autologous graft, which would not incite such an immune response.
questions.hint: Pain and edema within 6 months of receiving an allogeneic skin graft are signs of acute graft rejection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of an itchy lesion on her skin. The rash developed shortly after she took an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.3°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling of the face and raised, erythematous plaques on her trunk and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Secretion of cytokines by T cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of C1 inhibitor is the underlying pathology of bradykinin-mediated angioedema, which can be inherited or acquired. Lack of C1 inhibitor results in the unrestricted production of bradykinin, which mediates vasodilation and increased vascular permeability. Symptoms typically present as facial edema after a triggering event (e.g., ACE-inhibitor administration, infection), but do not include the urticaria or hypotension seen in this patient.
Image Description:

The severely swollen lower lip is most likely angioedema.

B) INCORRECT:

Activation of the complement cascade via binding of antibodies to cell surface antigens plays a major role in type II hypersensitivity reactions. Complement-mediated cell lysis and activation of NK cells and macrophages via their Fc receptors cause this inflammatory reaction. Common type II HSRs include hemolytic transfusion reactions, but instant allergic reactions upon intake of a certain drug, as seen in this patient, are not mediated by the complement cascade.

C) CORRECT:

The release of histamine, a vasoactive amine, plays an integral role in the type I hypersensitivity reaction seen in this patient. IgE antibodies from a previous encounter with a certain antigen are bound to mast cells and basophils. Re-exposure leads to degranulation of IgE-coated mast cells with release of histamine and various other mediators responsible for the characteristic features of type I HSR (i.e., erythema, pruritus, and urticaria). The patient's hypotension is due to hypovolemia caused by peripheral vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.
Image Description:

Well-circumscribed, pale papules (wheals) on an erythematous base (flare) can be seen on this patient's back.

D) INCORRECT:

Secretion of cytokines by T cells is essential for type IV hypersensitivity reactions, which result from delayed, cell-mediated cytotoxicity. Sensitization of CD4+ T cells to antigens (i.e., allergens) takes place via presentation by Langerhans cells in lymph nodes. Re-exposure to an antigen induces secretion of cytokines (e.g., IFN-γ) and subsequent activation of macrophages and T killer cells. However, this patient developed symptoms shortly after antigen exposure, which is inconsistent with a type IV HSR.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune complex deposition occurs with type III hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., serum sickness or vasculitis). Antibodies develop in response to a specific antigen, resulting in the formation of antigen-antibody immune complexes following second exposure. These immune complexes mainly deposit in vessel walls and trigger the complement cascade, initiating an inflammatory reaction. However, instant allergic reactions upon intake of a certain drug, as seen in this patient, are not mediated by the complement cascade.
questions.hint: The patient's acute-onset swelling and urticaria shortly after ingestion of an antibiotic are characteristic of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of weakness for one month. At the end of the day, she feels too fatigued to cook dinner or carry a laundry basket up the stairs. She also complains of double vision after she reads for long periods of time. All of her symptoms improve with rest. Her only medication is pravastatin. Physical examination shows drooping of the upper eyelids. Strength is initially 5/5 in the upper and lower extremities but decreases to 4/5 after a few minutes of sustained resistance. Sensation to light touch is intact and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Type II hypersensitivity reactions are characterized by antibody-mediated cellular destruction, cellular dysfunction, and/or inflammation. In myasthenia gravis, autoantibodies bind to post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in the inhibition of these receptors and impairing the process of neuromuscular transmission. Other examples of similar type II hypersensitivity reactions involving antibody-receptor binding include Graves disease and pemphigus vulgaris.
Image Description:

Blockade of ACh receptors (Left): ACh antibodies bind to postsynaptic ACh receptors and inhibit muscle activation.

Receptor internalization/degradation (middle): Binding of ACh antibody results in accelerated receptor degradation. The receptor is internalized and degraded by the muscle cell.

Complement activation (right): Binding of ACh autoantibodies results in complement activation and membrane attack complex formation, leading to the destruction of the neuromuscular junction and muscle cell lysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, and metachromatic leukodystrophy can cause muscle weakness due to demyelination of peripheral motor nerves. However, Guillain-Barré syndrome typically manifests with acute-onset ascending flaccid paralysis. Symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and metachromatic leukodystrophy typically begin during or before early adulthood, and loss of sensation (especially proprioception) is usually present. Nerve demyelination does not occur in myasthenia gravis.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction occurs in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which can cause diplopia and muscle weakness. However, patients with LEMS typically have diminished deep tendon reflexes and weakness that is worse in the morning, with symptoms usually improving by the end of the day and muscle strength increasing with repeated activity. Botulism is also associated with impaired acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction but patients with botulism have acute-onset, descending flaccid paralysis. Impaired acetylcholine release does not occur in myasthenia gravis.

D) INCORRECT:

Statin-induced myopathy is a known complication of statin therapy that typically manifests as symmetric, proximal muscle weakness (difficulties rising from chairs, raising the arms above the head, or climbing stairs). However, it often manifests with myalgia, which this patient does not have. Moreover, diplopia and improvement of symptoms with rest would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior horn cell destruction occurs in patients with poliomyelitis or motor neuron disease (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy). Poliomyelitis would manifest with acute-onset ascending flaccid paralysis. Muscle weakness due to spinal muscular atrophy begins during or before early adulthood and is associated with decreased deep tendon reflexes. The waxing-and-waning pattern of muscle weakness that is seen in this patient would not occur in either of these conditions.
questions.hint: Diplopia and muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest are highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of nausea, abdominal discomfort, and yellow discoloration of the eyes. Six weeks ago, he had an episode of fever, joint pain, swollen lymph nodes, and an itchy rash on his trunk and extremities that persisted for 1 to 2 days. He returned from a backpacking trip to Colombia two months ago. His temperature is 39°C (101.8°F). Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Infection with which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B is associated with a serum sickness-like reaction, which typically occurs during the prodromal period of the infection 1-2 weeks after antigen exposure and is thought to be mediated by immune complex formation. Symptoms of serum sickness-like reaction usually resolve within a few weeks, but symptoms from acute HBV infection may persist for longer, as seen in this patient. Other causes of serum sickness-like reaction include antibiotics (cefaclor, penicillin), streptococcal infection, and vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) infection is a common cause of traveler's diarrhea that can cause nausea, abdominal cramping, and fever, similar to the symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's history of rash and current jaundice would not be explained by ETEC. Furthermore, he is lacking the acute, watery diarrhea that is characteristic of ETEC infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne pathogen that causes Lyme disease. Patients with Lyme disease may present with fever, lymphadenopathy, transient arthritis, and jaundice. However, Lyme disease would typically present with erythema migrans, not an itchy rash involving the trunk and extremities.

D) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis (IM), which can manifest with fever, nausea, arthralgias, abdominal discomfort, jaundice, and lymphadenopathy. Although uncommon, a maculopapular rash can also occur in patients with IM. This patient, however, does not have other characteristic features of IM, such as pharyngitis, tonsillitis, and splenomegaly. Additionally, this patient had a prodromal syndrome about 6 weeks before his current symptoms, which does not occur in IM.

E) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacterium that classically causes bloody diarrhea but can also cause reactive arthritis, which may present similarly to this patient. However, it is not known to cause liver pathology and this patient is missing the classic symptoms of conjunctivitis and urethritis typically seen in reactive arthritis.
questions.hint: This patient's current condition (jaundice, nausea) suggest liver pathology, and his medical history suggests a serum sickness-like reaction (fever, arthritis, itchy rash).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 6-month history of worsening bronchial asthma control. Before this issue began, she only used her salbutamol inhaler once a day. Now, she has to use it multiple times daily and also reports frequent nighttime awakening. Seven months ago, she moved to an apartment that is damp and has mold on some of the walls. The physician injects 0.1 mL of Candida albicans extract on the mid-volar surface of the right arm intradermally. After 48 hours there is a palpable induration of 17 mm. This reaction is most likely a result of release of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In type I hypersensitivity reactions, antigens crosslink IgE bound to mast cells and basophils, stimulating the release of tryptase and vasoactive amines (e.g., histamine). These reactions usually manifest with pruritic rashes, hives, angioedema, and/or dyspnea within minutes after exposure to the antigen, whereas this patient's reactions did not manifest for 48 hours.

B) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-10 is secreted by regulatory T lymphocytes to downregulate the expression of MHC class II molecules, which decreases immune activation. In addition, Interleukin-10 inhibits the secretion of Th1 cytokines and suppresses activated macrophages and dendritic cells. It is not a mediator of hypersensitivity reactions.

C) INCORRECT:

Lysozyme is an antimicrobial enzyme that is a component of neutrophil, monocyte, and macrophage granules. It can lyse linkages in peptidoglycans (e.g., the cell wall of gram‑positive bacteria), making it important for innate immune response. This patient's isolated palpable induration 48 hours after exposure to an antigen is consistent with a type of hypersensitivity reaction, in which lysozyme has no major role.

D) INCORRECT:

Type II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies (immunoglobulin M and/or immunoglobulin G) bind cell-surface antigens. Type II hypersensitivity causes inflammation (e.g., Goodpasture syndrome and hyperacute transplant rejection), cell destruction (e.g., autoimmune hemolytic anemia, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, and Hashimoto thyroiditis), and/or cell dysfunction (e.g., myasthenia gravis or Graves disease). This patient's isolated palpable induration at the site of injection 48 hours after antigen exposure is consistent with a type of hypersensitivity reaction that is not mediated by immunoglobulin M.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's skin reaction 48 hours after injection of Candida extract suggests a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction (type IV hypersensitivity reaction). Candida antigens penetrating the skin are phagocytosed by Langerhans cells, which subsequently migrate to the lymph nodes and there induce the formation of sensitized T lymphocytes. On a subsequent exposure (e.g., Candida skin test), these sensitized T lymphocytes secrete interferon-γ, which induces macrophage-mediated tissue inflammation as seen in this patient. Other examples of diagnostic tests that evaluate for a type IV hypersensitivity reaction include tuberculin skin test and patch test.
Image Description:

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antigen-specific T cells, unlike all other hypersensitivity reactions, which are antibody-mediated. T helper cells (CD4+ cells; Th cells) mainly act by cytokine-mediated recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of the target cells.

T-cell receptors (TCR) present on sensitized CD4+ cells recognize and bind to specific exogenous antigens (e.g., bacteria, viruses). These antigens are bound to the major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC II), a transmembrane protein present on the surface of antigen-presenting cells, like macrophages. Th cells are divided into two subsets based on the cytokines they produce:
- Bacterial and viral infections predominantly activate Th1 cells, which release cytokines that preferentially recruit neutrophils and macrophages (e.g., IFNγ, TNFα). Activated macrophages release reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitric oxide (NO), which aid in the destruction of phagocytosed pathogens.
- Helminthic or parasitic infections predominantly activate Th2 cells, which release cytokines that preferentially recruit eosinophils (e.g., IL5). Activated eosinophils release major basic protein (MBP), which aids in the destruction of helminths and signals mast cells to release histamine.

Cytokines, ROS, and MBP recruit more inflammatory cells to the site of the reaction and amplify the inflammatory response, which typically becomes evident ∼ 48 hours after antigen-exposure (i.e., delayed hypersensitivity).

F) INCORRECT:

Superoxide anion is produced by neutrophils and monocytes as an intermediate in the formation of hydrogen peroxide during respiratory burst. While it facilitates bacterial destruction, it is not released by either of these cells and is not a mediator of hypersensitivity reactions.
questions.hint: This patient's increasingly frequent asthmatic attacks are most likely triggered by Candida albicans. The injection test described above can be used to assess cellular hypersensitivity to Candida albicans.

questions.text: Forty minutes after undergoing nasal polypectomy for refractory rhinitis, a 48-year-old woman develops chest tightness and shortness of breath. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated. She received ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago after the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. She has a history of asthma and hypertension. Her daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. Examination shows a flushed face, watery rhinorrhea, and conjunctival injection. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another underlying cause more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Prinzmetal angina typically manifests as periodic episodes of chest tightness and ischemic ECG changes are usually present during these episodes. However, this patient's ECG is normal. Moreover, clinical features of bronchospasm (e.g., wheezing with decreased breath sounds), a history of aspirin allergy, nasal polyps, and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause cutaneous flushing and bronchial inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

The use of nonselective beta blockers can result in bronchospasm due to inhibition of β2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta blocker that selectively inhibits β1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.

All beta blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta blockers are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin, which can result in a flushed face (due to angioedema) and wheezing due to the bronchoconstrictive effect of bradykinin. However, a history of aspirin allergy, nasal polyps, and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac suggest a different mechanism for bronchospasm.
questions.hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma constitutes Samter triad.

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation because of an episode of shortness of breath and swollen lips 2 weeks ago. He was dining with his friends at a seafood restaurant, where they ordered the "all you can eat" menu. Ten minutes after he started eating, he noticed a swelling of the lips, wheezing, and shortness of breath. His friends called 911 and he had to be transported to the emergency department for treatment and close observation after this episode. Today, his temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A skin prick test shows a positive result for salmon (7 mm) and cod (4 mm); there is no reactivity to shrimp. The patient enjoys eating seafood and wonders whether he can continue to eat other types of fish in the future. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Take antihistamines one hour before eating fish
Inject intramuscular norepinephrine after eating fish
Reduce the daily dietary amount of fish

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antihistamines can be used to treat mild allergic reactions such as urticaria, oral itch, or mild abdominal pain. This patient, however, had an anaphylactic reaction, for which treatment with antihistamines is insufficient. Furthermore, there is no recommendation that supports pretreatment with antihistamines in patients with IgE-mediated food allergies (e.g., fish allergy).

B) CORRECT:

Complete avoidance of the food allergen and similar foods is the preferred management for patients with food allergies. Although this patient's skin prick test is positive only for salmon and cod, he should also avoid all other types of finned fish because of a high risk of cross-reactivity. In addition, he should be counseled on cross-contacts (e.g., in restaurants), food allergens in unexpected sources or nonfood items, food labeling, and aerosolized allergens (e.g., in steam from cooking). Furthermore, all patients with IgE-mediated food allergies should be provided with an anaphylaxis emergency action plan and at least one epinephrine autoinjector to treat accidental exposure. In this patient who would like to continue eating seafood, a follow-up evaluation for shellfish tolerance may be considered because the most common allergens in finned fish typically differ from the allergens in shellfish and his skin prick test shows no reactivity to shrimp.

A new treatment approach for food allergies, oral immunotherapy (e.g., for peanut allergy), is currently being researched and consists of the ingestion of increasing doses of the allergen in a controlled setting in order to desensitize the immune system. This approach may allow patients with food allergies to continue eating allergenic foods in the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Some food allergens (especially milk and egg) are tolerated better when they are cooked or heated for a long time. However, there is only limited evidence that seafood boiled for a long time is less allergenic than raw seafood. This approach puts the patient at risk of another life-threatening allergic reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Although intramuscular epinephrine is used in the management of severe IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis due to fish allergy), this medication is reserved for emergency situations such as accidental exposure because it carries a high risk of side effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the amount of fish eaten daily is not an appropriate recommendation in a patient with a history of anaphylaxis caused by fish. This approach is insufficient because allergic reactions are typically triggered by even very small amounts of allergen.
questions.hint: This patient has had an anaphylactic reaction after ingesting fish. His skin prick test confirms a food allergy to salmon and cod. The physician's recommendation should take into account future reactions and potential cross-reactivity.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 22 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I want to have this mole on my left cheek removed because I don't like how it looks, and I'm afraid it will turn into skin cancer.”
History of Present Illness:

mole on left cheek since age 11 years

lesion has been growing in size; used to be flat and dark brown; now elevated and light brown
several moles on upper body
moles have increased in number since childhood; some have disappeared since adolescence

Past Medical History:
wisdom tooth extraction 6 months ago under local anesthesia; 24 hours later, local swelling, itching, and blistering at injection sites; anesthetic agent unknown

Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
local anesthetics
Family History:
noncontributory
Psychosocial History:

lives with parents
works as a market gardener
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
