36.9°C(98.4°F)
60/min
14/min
100/65 mm Hg
98% on RA
163 cm(5 ft 4 in)
57 kg(125 lb)
21.5 kg/m2




Appearance: no acute distress
Skin: warm, dry, and intact; 1 raised, papillomatous, uniformly light brown lesion with regular borders on left cheek, 5 mm in diameter; 7 similar lesions and 20 flat, well-demarcated light brown macules on upper trunk, shoulders, neck, and upper arms
HEENT: PERRLA
Neck: no cervical lymphadenopathy or masses
Pulmonary: clear lung fields bilaterally
Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of cetirizine followed by local anesthetic of choice
Mole removal with lidocaine as local anesthetic
Mole removal with procaine as local anesthetic
Referral to an allergist before mole removal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

General anesthesia has a higher risk of respiratory and cardiovascular complications than local anesthesia. Although general anesthesia is an option for urgent surgery, it is unwarranted for the elective removal of a mole, which can be performed under local anesthesia.

B) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines like cetirizine can reduce mild allergic symptoms (e.g., urticaria) in IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reactions by blocking or inhibiting histamine receptors. However, they are generally ineffective for treating allergic contact dermatitis, which is a T cell-mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Although lidocaine can be administered for elective mole removal, this patient has previously developed allergic contact dermatitis to an unspecified local anesthetic. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Although procaine can be administered for elective mole removal, this patient has previously developed allergic contact dermatitis to an unspecified local anesthetic. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Local swelling, itching, and blistering 12–48 hours after injection of a local anesthetic are consistent with allergic contact dermatitis to an unknown agent. Referral to an allergist to determine the causal local anesthetic is appropriate before proceeding with elective surgery.

Cross-reactivity between ester group anesthetics and amide group anesthetics is rare; therefore, if an allergy to one group is found, an anesthetic from the other group can be safely administered in future procedures.
questions.hint: Removal of a benign skin lesion, such as a common acquired melanocytic nevus (i.e., mole), is considered elective surgery.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being bitten in the leg by a rattlesnake while hiking. Soon after arriving, he begins developing systemic symptoms, and snake antivenom is administered. His symptoms improve, and he is discharged home. Twelve days later, he starts experiencing intermittent fevers to 38.1°C, a serpiginous maculopapular eruption on his legs, and mild joint pain in his hands.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin E-mediated allergy to snake antivenom

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain drugs may cause hypersensitivity vasculitis reactions, but this type of reaction has not been associated with administration of snake antivenom.

B) INCORRECT:

Type I (immunoglobulin E-mediated) hypersensitivity reactions require previous sensitization to a food, drug, or heterologous protein, and they are generally immediate in nature. The immunoglobulin E-mediated activation of mast cells results in a vasoactive response, with clinical manifestations such as anaphylaxis, bronchospasm, and hives.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyrogenic reactions to antivenom are caused by pyrogen contamination during manufacture and may include chills, rigors, fever, myalgia, headache, tachycardia, and hypotension secondary to vasodilation. Bacterial lipopolysaccharides are the most common pyrogens in antivenoms. Reactions typically occur within the first hour after antivenom administration.

D) INCORRECT:

Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reactions are T-cell mediated and do not manifest with fever or joint pain.

E) CORRECT:

The timing of symptom onset and the nature of the symptoms in this case are crucial in determining if the patient is experiencing a type III hypersensitivity reaction to the previously administered heterologous protein.

Type III (serum-sickness) hypersensitivity reactions typically appear 7 to 14 days after a patient receives heterologous nonhuman serum proteins. The formation of immune complexes, which deposit in vessels or tissue and trigger complement activation, results in serpiginous maculopapular eruptions, fever, and joint pain, as this patient is experiencing.

Key learning point: The length of time between the administration of a heterologous protein snake antivenom and the development of a serum-sickness hypersensitivity reaction is typically 1 to 2 weeks.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man, who was once an avid hunter, received a heart transplant 5 years ago for a cardiomyopathy. He received a dose of rabbit antithymocyte globulin (ATG) at the time of transplantation and then again 2 years later for treatment of rejection. Recently, he developed shortness of breath, and his cardiac function was found to be markedly reduced. He was thought to be having another rejection episode and was again treated with rabbit ATG as well as with glucocorticoids. Ten days after receiving the ATG, the patient developed a fever, a rash (figure), and arthralgias of the knees, wrists, ankles, and shoulders.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of transplant rejection include fatigue, shortness of breath, edema, and low-grade fever. Arthralgias and morbilliform rashes are not characteristic of rejection reactions.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is rare in adults. It occurs after pharyngitis caused by group A Streptococcus. The typical rash of rheumatic fever is erythema marginatum, not a morbilliform rash.

C) CORRECT:

Type III hypersensitivity reactions, also known as serum sickness reactions, can cause fever, joint pain, and rash that start 7 to 10 days after exposure to heterologous nonhuman serum proteins. These reactions are caused by the formation of immune complexes that consist of the heterologous protein and protein-specific immunoglobulins. There are currently no methods to predict who will develop serum sickness. Risk factors in this patient include prior exposure to the antigen through previous exposure to rabbit antithymocyte globulin as well as probable exposure to rabbits while hunting.

Key learning point: The development of joint pain, rash, and fever 7 to 10 days after treatment with rabbit antithymocyte globulin in someone who had previously received this agent is most consistent with the diagnosis of serum sickness (type III hypersensitivity reaction).

D) INCORRECT:

The skin manifestations of bacterial endocarditis are typically petechiae and splinter hemorrhages, not a morbilliform rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions typically occur 24 to 48 hours after administration of the offending agent, and the clinical features range from mild contact dermatitis to severe exfoliative dermatitis. Although fever can occur with severe reactions, a morbilliform eruption is not a typical feature of any of them.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man who is currently hospitalized for treatment of acute pancreatitis reports increasing abdominal pain. His gastroenterologist recommends a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to evaluate for pancreatic necrosis. While you are counseling the patient about the risks and benefits of this study, he mentions that many years ago he had an allergic reaction, including flushing, pruritus, and wheezing, about one hour after receiving intravenous contrast. He has not received intravenous contrast since then.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Proceed with the scan using nonionic low-osmolality contrast media, and consider premedication with a glucocorticoid and an antihistamine
Prescribe oral N-acetylcysteine 1200 mg before the CT scan, and repeat administration every 12 hours for 2 days
Administer one liter of sodium bicarbonate solution immediately before the CT scan
Start 0.9% normal saline 2 hours before the CT scan, and continue for 6 hours afterward
Administer an intravenous test dose of contrast, and monitor for any reaction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients commonly report allergic reactions to intravenous (IV) contrast — typically flushing, pruritus, and wheezing shortly after receipt of contrast, as reported by this patient. The exact pathogenesis of these reactions is not well understood but is thought to be related to the release of histamine and other vasoactive mediators from basophils and mast cells.

Patients who have had one episode of hypersensitivity to IV contrast are at increased risk for another. Thus, in the past, premedication with a glucocorticoid and an antihistamine was recommended for these patients. However, a joint guideline committee from the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology and the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology evaluated the data around this practice and found no benefit from it (risk ratio for anaphylaxis, 1.07; 95% confidence interval 0.67–1.71). As a result, current guidelines do not suggest routinely administering premedication in this scenario. However, they do recommend using low- or iso-osmolar nonionic radiocontrast media. High-osmolality contrast media are no longer in use, given their high rates of adverse reactions, including physiologic and allergic reactions.

The latest guidelines do acknowledge that the quality of the evidence in this area is low and thus leave open the option of using premedication “in clinical circumstances associated with a high level of perceived risk of anaphylaxis or comorbidities associated with greater anaphylaxis fatality risk (such as underlying cardiovascular disease, use of beta-blockers, or prior severe anaphylaxis).” Thus, some clinicians might consider administering premedication with a glucocorticoid, an antihistamine, or both in this setting.

Key learning point: Previous guidelines recommended administering premedication with a glucocorticoid and an antihistamine before conducting contrast-enhanced CT imaging in patients who had a history of an immediate hypersensitivity reaction to intravenous contrast. However, the latest guidelines recommend proceeding without premedication and using nonionic low- or iso-osmolar contrast media.

B) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is a controversial preventive measure for contrast-induced nephropathy that has not consistently been shown to be effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Bicarbonate-rich fluids have been suggested for reducing the risk for contrast-induced nephropathy, but there is no clear benefit to using them instead of normal saline, and the focus in this case is on preventing hypersensitivity reactions, not nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous volume expansion with isotonic fluids can be used to reduce the risk for contrast-induced nephropathy but has no role in preventing hypersensitivity reactions to IV contrast.

E) INCORRECT:

Using a test dose of contrast to assess for a reaction has been shown to be ineffective both in reducing the incidence of contrast reactions and in indicating whether a reaction will occur with a standard injection. This practice is therefore not recommended.

questions.text:
A healthy 10-year-old girl eats a cookie given to her by a friend in the school cafeteria. Ten minutes later, she develops a generalized urticarial rash. She is immediately brought to the emergency department, where she is noted to have normal vital signs, clear lungs, a clear oropharynx, and diffuse hives and itching.
Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Intramuscular epinephrine and an oral antihistamine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient without known allergies, an allergic reaction is considered to be anaphylaxis if there is involvement of skin or mucosal tissue (e.g., generalized hives; pruritus or flushing; swollen lips, tongue, or uvula), plus at least one of the following:

• Respiratory compromise
• Reduced blood pressure or associated symptoms of end-organ dysfunction
• Persistent gastrointestinal symptoms (significant abdominal pain, vomiting, or both)

Anaphylactic reactions should be treated with intramuscular epinephrine. Glucocorticoids and nebulized albuterol may be given as adjuncts in cases of anaphylaxis but should never delay the administration of intramuscular epinephrine in such cases.

Given that this patient has only cutaneous symptoms, she does not need to be treated for anaphylaxis at this time. If symptoms worsen, the patient may require additional treatment.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is having an acute reaction to an unknown allergen, likely one she ingested in the cookie shared with her. Although she is likely suffering from intense urticaria-related pruritus, her symptoms do not meet the criteria for anaphylaxis and so can be treated with an oral antihistamine alone. She should be monitored for worsening of symptoms, and upon discharge, her caregivers should be given anticipatory guidance regarding the signs of anaphylaxis.

In a patient without known allergies, an allergic reaction is considered to be anaphylaxis if there is involvement of skin or mucosal tissue (e.g., generalized hives; pruritus or flushing; swollen lips, tongue, or uvula), plus at least one of the following:

• Respiratory compromise
• Reduced blood pressure or associated symptoms of end-organ dysfunction
• Persistent gastrointestinal symptoms (significant abdominal pain, vomiting, or both)

Anaphylactic reactions should be treated with intramuscular epinephrine. Glucocorticoids and nebulized albuterol may be given as adjuncts in cases of anaphylaxis but should never delay the administration of intramuscular epinephrine in such cases.

Given that this patient has only cutaneous symptoms, she does not need to be treated for anaphylaxis at this time. If symptoms worsen, the patient may require additional treatment.

Key learning point: The treatment of choice for an acute allergic reaction without systemic symptoms is an oral antihistamine.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient is having an acute reaction to an unknown allergen, likely one she ingested in the cookie shared with her. Although she is likely suffering from intense urticaria-related pruritus, her symptoms do not meet the criteria for anaphylaxis and so can be treated with an oral antihistamine alone. She should be monitored for worsening of symptoms, and upon discharge, her caregivers should be given anticipatory guidance regarding the signs of anaphylaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient without known allergies, an allergic reaction is considered to be anaphylaxis if there is involvement of skin or mucosal tissue (e.g., generalized hives; pruritus or flushing; swollen lips, tongue, or uvula), plus at least one of the following:

• Respiratory compromise
• Reduced blood pressure or associated symptoms of end-organ dysfunction
• Persistent gastrointestinal symptoms (significant abdominal pain, vomiting, or both)

Anaphylactic reactions should be treated with intramuscular epinephrine. Glucocorticoids and nebulized albuterol may be given as adjuncts in cases of anaphylaxis but should never delay the administration of intramuscular epinephrine in such cases.

Given that this patient has only cutaneous symptoms, she does not need to be treated for anaphylaxis at this time. If symptoms worsen, the patient may require additional treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient without known allergies, an allergic reaction is considered to be anaphylaxis if there is involvement of skin or mucosal tissue (e.g., generalized hives; pruritus or flushing; swollen lips, tongue, or uvula), plus at least one of the following:

• Respiratory compromise
• Reduced blood pressure or associated symptoms of end-organ dysfunction
• Persistent gastrointestinal symptoms (significant abdominal pain, vomiting, or both)

Anaphylactic reactions should be treated with intramuscular epinephrine. Glucocorticoids and nebulized albuterol may be given as adjuncts in cases of anaphylaxis but should never delay the administration of intramuscular epinephrine in such cases.

Given that this patient has only cutaneous symptoms, she does not need to be treated for anaphylaxis at this time. If symptoms worsen, the patient may require additional treatment.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a pruritic rash on his penis that has been present for the past hour. The rash developed shortly after the patient had protected sexual intercourse with his girlfriend for the first time. His girlfriend does not have any symptoms. Two years ago, the patient developed an itchy rash around his mouth after blowing up balloons at a birthday party. He is breathing comfortably. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques with mild excoriations that extend from the base to the glans of the penis. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat certain viral infections, e.g., herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. While HSV infection should be considered as a differential diagnosis in a sexually active patient presenting with a genital rash, the timing and appearance of his rash are not consistent with this diagnosis (HSV typically appears 2–7 days after exposure and is characterized by vesicles and ulcerations). Furthermore, oral acyclovir is preferred over IV administration for genital HSV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous epinephrine is used for the treatment of anaphylaxis, a severe form of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. While urticaria is a common feature in anaphylaxis, this patient has no other symptoms to suggest it (e.g., bronchospasm, laryngeal edema, abdominal pain, hypotension). A different therapy is more appropriate for a mild to moderate localized reaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Famotidine is an H2 receptor blocker commonly used for the treatment of GERD and can also be used in the treatment of anaphylaxis. While acute-onset urticaria after exposure to a potential allergen should raise concern for anaphylaxis, this patient has no other symptoms to suggest anaphylaxis (e.g., bronchospasm, laryngeal edema, abdominal pain, hypotension) or GERD. A different therapy is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a potent anti-inflammatory that has many uses, including the treatment of certain hypersensitivity reactions. Because glucocorticoids can cause serious systemic side effects, they are typically reserved for moderate to severe type 1 hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., angioedema, pronounced urticaria). If glucocorticoids are used for the treatment of urticaria, oral rather than intravenous administration is preferred. This patient has a mild to moderate localized hypersensitivity reaction, making another treatment more appropriate.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's localized urticaria is consistent with a mild to moderate type 1 hypersensitivity reaction to latex, for which an H1-antihistamine such as cetirizine is indicated. Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are caused by preformed IgE antibodies (from prior sensitization), which then activate rapid histamine release from mast cells upon reexposure to the antigen. Cetirizine competes with histamine at the H1 receptor to stabilize mast cells and is less sedating than first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine, hydroxyzine). This patient should also be advised to avoid contact with latex in the future.
Image Description:

Anterior upper body of a man presenting with a pruritic rash after consuming peanuts

Multiple well-defined, raised, erythematous plaques of varying sizes are visible on the upper left abdomen and inner arm. The largest lesion on the trunk shows central clearing.

This is the typical appearance of urticaria (hives).
questions.hint: The eruption of an urticarial rash on the patient's penis shortly after protected sexual intercourse and history of a rash following exposure to balloons suggest a hypersensitivity reaction to latex.

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation because of an episode of shortness of breath and swollen lips 2 weeks ago. Ten minutes after he started eating seafood, he noticed a swelling of the lips, wheezing, and shortness of breath. He had to be transported to the emergency department for treatment and close observation after this episode. A skin prick test shows a positive result for salmon and cod; there is no reactivity to shrimp. The patient enjoys eating seafood and wonders whether he can continue to eat other types of fish in the future. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Take antihistamines one hour before eating fish
Inject intramuscular norepinephrine after eating fish
Reduce the daily dietary amount of fish

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antihistamines can be used to treat mild allergic reactions such as urticaria, oral itch, or mild abdominal pain. This patient, however, had an anaphylactic reaction, for which treatment with antihistamines is insufficient. Furthermore, there is no recommendation that supports pretreatment with antihistamines in patients with IgE-mediated food allergies (e.g., fish allergy).

B) CORRECT:

Complete avoidance of the food allergen and similar foods is the preferred management for patients with food allergies. Although this patient's skin prick test is positive only for salmon and cod, he should also avoid all other types of finned fish because of a high risk of cross-reactivity. In addition, he should be counseled on cross-contacts (e.g., in restaurants), food allergens in unexpected sources or nonfood items, food labeling, and aerosolized allergens (e.g., in steam from cooking). Furthermore, all patients with IgE-mediated food allergies should be provided with an anaphylaxis emergency action plan and at least one epinephrine autoinjector to treat accidental exposure. In this patient who would like to continue eating seafood, a follow-up evaluation for shellfish tolerance may be considered because the most common allergens in finned fish typically differ from the allergens in shellfish and his skin prick test shows no reactivity to shrimp.

A new treatment approach for food allergies, oral immunotherapy (e.g., for peanut allergy), is currently being researched and consists of the ingestion of increasing doses of the allergen in a controlled setting in order to desensitize the immune system. This approach may allow patients with food allergies to continue eating allergenic foods in the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Some food allergens (especially milk and egg) are tolerated better when they are cooked or heated for a long time. However, there is only limited evidence that seafood boiled for a long time is less allergenic than raw seafood. This approach puts the patient at risk of another life-threatening allergic reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Although intramuscular epinephrine is used in the management of severe IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis due to fish allergy), this medication is reserved for emergency situations such as accidental exposure because it carries a high risk of side effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the amount of fish eaten daily is not an appropriate recommendation in a patient with a history of anaphylaxis caused by fish. This approach is insufficient because allergic reactions are typically triggered by even very small amounts of allergen.
questions.hint: This patient has had an anaphylactic reaction after ingesting fish. His skin prick test confirms a food allergy to salmon and cod. The health care provider's recommendation should take into account future reactions and potential cross-reactivity.

questions.text: You are seeing an 18-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a pruritic rash on his penis that began one hour ago. The rash developed shortly after he had protected sexual intercourse with his girlfriend for the first time. His girlfriend does not have any symptoms. He reports a history of an itchy rash around his mouth two years ago after blowing up balloons at a birthday party. He is breathing comfortably. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are multiple well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques with mild excoriations extending from the base to the glans of the penis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's localized urticaria is consistent with a mild to moderate type 1 hypersensitivity reaction to latex, for which an H1-antihistamine such as cetirizine is indicated. Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are caused by preformed IgE antibodies (from prior sensitization), which then activate rapid histamine release from mast cells upon reexposure to the antigen. Cetirizine competes with histamine at the H1 receptor to stabilize mast cells and is less sedating than first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine, hydroxyzine). This patient should also be advised to avoid contact with latex in the future.

Key learning point: Mild to moderate localized type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, such as latex-induced urticaria, are best managed with oral H1-antihistamines like cetirizine.
Image Description:

Anterior upper body of a man presenting with a pruritic rash after consuming peanuts

Multiple well-defined, raised, erythematous plaques of varying sizes are visible on the upper left abdomen and inner arm. The largest lesion on the trunk shows central clearing.

This is the typical appearance of urticaria (hives).

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat certain viral infections, e.g., herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. While HSV infection should be considered as a differential diagnosis in a sexually active patient presenting with a genital rash, the timing and appearance of his rash are not consistent with this diagnosis (HSV typically appears 2–7 days after exposure and is characterized by vesicles and ulcerations). Furthermore, oral acyclovir is preferred over IV administration for genital HSV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous epinephrine is used for the treatment of anaphylaxis, a severe form of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. While urticaria is a common feature in anaphylaxis, this patient has no other symptoms to suggest it (e.g., bronchospasm, laryngeal edema, abdominal pain, hypotension). A different therapy is more appropriate for a mild to moderate localized reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a potent anti-inflammatory that has many uses, including the treatment of certain hypersensitivity reactions. Because glucocorticoids can cause serious systemic side effects, they are typically reserved for moderate to severe type 1 hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., angioedema, pronounced urticaria). If glucocorticoids are used for the treatment of urticaria, oral rather than intravenous administration is preferred. This patient has a mild to moderate localized hypersensitivity reaction, making another treatment more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Famotidine is an H2 receptor blocker commonly used for the treatment of GERD and can also be used in the treatment of anaphylaxis. While acute-onset urticaria after exposure to a potential allergen should raise concern for anaphylaxis, this patient has no other symptoms to suggest anaphylaxis (e.g., bronchospasm, laryngeal edema, abdominal pain, hypotension) or GERD. A different therapy is more appropriate.
questions.hint: The eruption of an urticarial rash on the patient's penis shortly after protected sexual intercourse and history of a rash following exposure to balloons suggest a hypersensitivity reaction to latex.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of fever and rash that began 3 weeks after starting phenytoin. She appears ill with facial edema and cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination reveals a generalized morbilliform rash covering 60% of her body surface area. Laboratory studies show: WBC 12,800/mm3 with 15% eosinophils, hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL, platelets 145,000/mm3, AST 128 U/L, ALT 156 U/L, and creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate drug hypersensitivity reactions typically occur within 1 hour of drug exposure and manifest with urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, or anaphylaxis. The delayed onset of 3 weeks and presence of facial edema with organ involvement are not consistent with immediate hypersensitivity reactions.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – DRESS syndrome is characterized by delayed onset 2-8 weeks after drug exposure, fever, diffuse morbilliform rash, facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and internal organ involvement. Facial edema is a common feature of DRESS that is not typically seen in other severe cutaneous adverse reactions. The liver is the most commonly affected organ in DRESS, and kidney involvement can also occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed drug eruption presents as well-defined, erythematous lesions that are often solitary and occur within 8 hours of drug exposure. The generalized morbilliform rash pattern and systemic organ involvement seen in this patient are not characteristic of fixed drug eruption.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically has an onset of 1-3 weeks after drug exposure and is characterized by bullous lesions, positive Nikolsky sign, and significant mucosal involvement. This patient's morbilliform rash pattern and lack of bullous lesions make Stevens-Johnson syndrome less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Exanthematous drug eruption presents as a morbilliform rash on the trunk and proximal extremities with typical onset 5-14 days after drug exposure. However, it does not typically involve facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, or internal organ involvement as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after consuming lobster at a dinner party. He reports generalized pruritus and a new rash on his chest and arms. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows mild perioral edema. The appearance of the skin rash is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with acute urticaria following exposure to a known allergen, a classic type I hypersensitivity reaction. Second-generation antihistamines are the first-line treatment for symptomatic management of urticaria alongside trigger avoidance. The patient has localized skin manifestations without systemic signs of anaphylaxis, making antihistamines the most appropriate initial therapy. Treatment should be scheduled rather than on-demand until the hives resolve. Referral to an allergist for allergy testing can also be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated for anaphylaxis when diagnostic criteria are met, including hypotension, respiratory involvement, or multi-system organ involvement. While this patient has mild perioral edema, he lacks cardiovascular or respiratory compromise that would warrant immediate epinephrine administration.

C) INCORRECT:

Tryptase levels can support a diagnosis of mast cell activation in Type I reactions, but laboratory confirmation is not necessary when the clinical presentation is clear. This test does not alter immediate management, and results are not available immediately in the acute setting due to a prolonged turnaround time.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic corticosteroids are typically reserved for severe urticaria exacerbations or may be considered in Type IV delayed hypersensitivity reactions with significant inflammation. The acute onset and urticarial pattern in this case do not warrant initial corticosteroid therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids might be appropriate for localized contact dermatitis from Type IV delayed hypersensitivity reactions. However, this patient's systemic urticaria with rapid onset after allergen exposure requires systemic treatment rather than topical therapy alone.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after eating at a restaurant. He reports facial swelling and itchy skin lesions. Examination shows bilateral periorbital and lip swelling, generalized urticaria, and clear lung sounds. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 88; R, 16; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. He has no voice changes, difficulty swallowing, nausea, or abdominal pain. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Icatibant is a bradykinin-B2 receptor antagonist used for bradykinin-mediated angioedema, particularly hereditary angioedema. This patient's presentation with urticaria after food exposure suggests histamine-mediated rather than bradykinin-mediated angioedema.

B) INCORRECT:

Fresh frozen plasma is a second-line treatment for bradykinin-mediated angioedema, especially ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema. This patient's acute onset symptoms after food exposure with concurrent urticaria indicates a histamine-mediated pathophysiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylprednisolone is used as adjunctive therapy in severe allergic reactions or as part of anaphylaxis management. Antihistamines remain the first-line treatment for isolated urticaria and angioedema without systemic involvement.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Diphenhydramine is the most appropriate first-line treatment for histamine-mediated angioedema and urticaria when anaphylaxis criteria are not met. This patient has isolated skin and mucosal involvement without cardiovascular or respiratory compromise, indicating a type I hypersensitivity reaction, which should respond well to antihistamines.

E) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated when anaphylaxis criteria are met (e.g., known allergen exposure with hypotension, acute illness with skin and/or mucosal symptoms plus cardiovascular and/or respiratory symptoms). This patient has stable vital signs without respiratory distress or cardiovascular compromise.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, joint pain, and a rash that developed over the past 2 days. He was treated with crotaline antivenom (CroFab) 2 weeks ago for a rattlesnake bite. Physical examination shows a temperature of 101.5°F (38.6°C), symmetric arthritis of his wrists and ankles, and an urticarial rash on his trunk and extremities. His neck is supple and neurological examination is normal. Complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are unremarkable. Urinalysis shows mild proteinuria. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain blood cultures and start empiric antibiotics
Order rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies
Perform lumbar puncture and CSF analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine and high-dose corticosteroids are indicated for anaphylaxis, a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs within minutes to hours of exposure. This patient has a delayed reaction occurring weeks after exposure and does not require emergency anaphylaxis treatment.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction that typically occurs 1–3 weeks after antivenom administration. The classic triad includes fever, arthralgias, and rash (urticarial or purpuric). Treatment involves systemic corticosteroids, H1 blockers, and NSAIDs for symptomatic relief. The condition is self-limited once the offending antigen is cleared.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures and antibiotics would be appropriate for suspected septic arthritis or bacteremia. However, the symmetric joint involvement, timing relative to antivenom administration, and characteristic rash pattern make serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, the most likely diagnosis rather than infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies are used to evaluate for rheumatoid arthritis. While serum sickness can mimic inflammatory arthritis, the acute onset following antivenom administration and associated rash make serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, more likely than autoimmune arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture and CSF analysis would be indicated for suspected meningitis if the patient had signs of meningeal irritation or altered mental status. This patient's presentation with fever, rash, and arthritis following recent antivenom exposure is consistent with serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, rather than central nervous system infection.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum. During this time, he has also noticed blood in his urine. He has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Urinalysis is positive for blood and results of a direct enzyme-linked immunoassay are positive for anti-GBM antibodies. The pathogenesis of this patient's disease is most similar to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A vasculitis (formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction involving the deposition of circulating IgA-immune complexes in the walls of small vessels throughout the body (e.g., skin, GI tract, joints, kidneys). Immune complex deposition does not play a significant role in the pathogenesis of Goodpasture syndrome, which this patient has.
Image Description:

Maculopapular, reddish, non-blanching, palpable skin lesions (purpura) are seen on both the distal right arm and leg. On the lower leg, the lesions are partially confluent and present with scaling and erosion.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction involving immune complex deposition and typically affects small and medium-sized vessels throughout the body (e.g., skin, CNS, GI tract). Immune complex deposition is not a significant feature in the pathogenesis of Goodpasture syndrome, which this patient has.

C) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction that involves the formation and deposition of immune complexes (IgM, IgG) and complement components in the glomerular basement membrane. Immune complex deposition is not a significant feature in the pathogenesis of Goodpasture syndrome, which this patient has.

D) CORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is a type II hypersensitivity reaction involving IgG-mediated or IgM-mediated destruction of red blood cells. Its pathogenesis is similar to Goodpasture syndrome, which is also caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction that involves the formation of autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the glomerular and alveolar basement membrane. In type II hypersensitivity reactions, tissue damage can occur due to complement-mediated cell lysis and/or cell-mediated cytotoxicity resulting from opsonization of macrophages and NK cells. Other examples of type II hypersensitivity reactions include acute hemolytic transfusion reactions, bullous pemphigoid, and pemphigus vulgaris.

See “Hypersensitivity classification” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction involving damage to the recipient's tissue by donor T cells. GvHD is an example of a cell-mediated (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction caused by sensitized T cells rather than the tissue-specific antibody formation seen in Goodpasture disease.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, hematuria, and anti-GBM antibodies on direct enzyme-linked immunoassay suggest Goodpasture syndrome, a type of pulmonary-renal syndrome.
